feed.title: Combined summary - Scaling Lightning With Simple Covenants

entry.title: Combined summary - Scaling Lightning With Simple Covenants
entry.summary:
The email exchange discusses various topics related to Lightning Network and its scalability and usability improvements. John introduces a new version of the paper that addresses fragmentation costs and proposes solutions such as requiring casual users to reveal secrets and adding a fee-penalty output. Passive rollovers are highlighted as a way to eliminate the risk of HTLC-withholding attacks. Antoine agrees with John's points and suggests on-chain splicing and pool rebalancing as potential solutions for transactional scaling challenges. He also raises concerns about attacks on dedicated users with multiple off-chain trees and suggests using "cut-through" to reduce the on-chain footprint in mass exit cases.
The email also covers the use of covenants, timeout-trees, and FFO-WF protocol variations to create Lightning channels for millions of casual users without complex coordination or signatures. Additionally, it discusses addressing the availability problem when draining funds from an old timeout-tree to a new one and highlights the importance of providing immediately-accessible off-chain bitcoin.
The protocols enabling Lightning sends and receives to be conducted off-chain are mentioned, along with their ability to allow for multiple Lightning channels per casual user. The email emphasizes the inclusion of mechanisms like CTV or APO in Bitcoin's consensus rules to make Lightning a widely-used means of payment.
While highlighting the benefits of off-chain transactions, the email acknowledges the cost of resolving HTLCs on-chain and the challenge of reliable relay of transaction packages. It concludes with the hope that mechanisms like CTV or APO will be added to Bitcoin's consensus rules to improve scalability, usability, and address limitations.
